triples.name: Bantu languages
triples.relevance: The paper investigates emphatic interpretations of object marking across multiple Bantu languages including Lubukusu and Cinyungwe.

triples.name: Bukusu dialect
triples.relevance: Lubukusu is a Luhya language variety and serves as one of the primary research subjects for analyzing emphatic object marking.

triples.name: Nyungwe language
triples.relevance: Cinyungwe (Nyungwe) is a Bantu language of Mozambique used as a primary case study for emphatic interpretations of object marking.

triples.name: Idaxo-Isuxa-Tiriki language
triples.relevance: Tiriki is used as additional evidence for emphatic interpretations of object marking in the comparative analysis across Bantu languages.

triples.name: Luhya people
triples.relevance: Wanga is one of the Luhya language varieties studied for emphatic object marking interpretations.

triples.name: Kalanga language
triples.relevance: Ikalanga is included as evidence for emphatic interpretations of object marking in the broader Bantu language family.

triples.name: Differential object marking
triples.relevance: Object marking is a core linguistic phenomenon investigated in the paper, particularly in contexts of OM-doubling.

triples.name: Implicature
triples.relevance: The paper proposes analyzing emphatic interpretations of OM-doubling as conventional implicatures.

triples.name: Focus (linguistics)
triples.relevance: The paper compares emphatic interpretations of object marking to similar emphatic effects from focus fronting in Indo-European languages.

triples.name: Mirativity
triples.relevance: The paper identifies mirativity as one of four types of emphatic interpretations arising from OM-doubling in Bantu languages.

triples.name: Exhaustivity
triples.relevance: The paper identifies exhaustivity as one of four types of emphatic interpretations arising from OM-doubling in Bantu languages.
